reviews.review_msg: Dr. Taylor is such a good prof. I learned so much in his class. If you put in the effort, watch the recorded lectures, and ask questions, you'll get a lot out of this class. He's also very supportive when it comes to writing tips and resources.

It's clear he's very passionate about his field as he would often go on tangents when asked questions. He's quite a tough marker but he leaves lots of feedback and simply wants you to improve. Would take again as he made me interested in US history!

Dr. Taylor was a great professor. He is very passionate and provides a lot of details in his lectures. The exams are generally fair because he warns you about the format beforehand but beware of his questioning it can be confusing. He is open to having more discussions and is very approachable. His quizzes are also very straightforward.

Do NOT take this if you don't need it. This is a 100 level course... I'm at the end of my 2nd year & this is the most demanding course I've ever taken. Several long and difficult readings every week. Long and boring lectures. Quizzes weekly. Essay instructions was literally 3 sentences. Not enough time to write exams (short answer and 2 essays)

Very passionate about his field, very approachable, and gives lots of feedback/answers to questions. Lots of papers but they're expected to be pretty short, concise, and to the point. Workload was reading a book (~300 pages) every other week and writing a short book review + presentation (no slides needed) on zoom. Easy grader in my opinion as well

He does not allow any technology in class... I was forced to handwrite all my notes then type them after which wasted so much time that I could of been actually studying the notes and material. He was also very particular about how you give test answers. Will never take another class with Joseph.

I had joseph taylor for spring 2021 (hist 432) and i just wanna say i never worked so hard just to get a B. The entire class was graded one group papers (50%) and presentations/participation (50%). He grades pretty hard but gives lots of feedback. I didnt find him very approachable

Dr Taylor is great. I think he struggled with online teaching but he did his best to adjust (this was during Covid-19). Lots of lectures but if you're passionate about history then it's definitely a fun class. Tough marker but you'll find yourself improving if you take his feedback.

Professor Taylor is a great prof and gives interesting lectures about the material which he is clearly passionate about. Participation is heavily encouraged in the weekly discussions. The course is interesting, but the lectures are long and there's a lot of reading. He's a hard marker, but that's just because he actually wants you to improve.

Like many others, I was intimidated by Professor Taylor on the first day of classes. However as the semester went on I began to look forward to his lectures more and more. He truly cares about his students and has a vast amount of knowledge on the American West. Assigns a lot of readings but they are essential to his tests and assignments.

Intro history class involved plenty of reading but that's pretty normal. Prof Taylor is a really nice guy who knows his content inside out. Personally, listening to him talk is absolutely fascinating, real mental stimulation. Tutorials were sort of a waste of time content wise, but we did get a lot of useful exam hints.

Based on what people said, I was terrified on the first day. Tons of reading, quiz every lecture (even day 1) and intimidating guy. By the end of this semester, I wanted to take another class with him. Really smart prof who cares about students and wants you to really think about the material. Amazing class and phenomenal scholar.

Too many readings for an intro class. Lectures don't have useful slides (all pictures). In fact, the lectures I feel don't provide enough foundation for the average student (esp those without a HIST background). Tutorials are a waste of time. There's only one hour to dive into three dense articles. And the pop quizzes every class. Terrible.

Dr. Taylor is amazing with fascinating lectures, but get ready for picture-only slides. The course is extremely reading heavy (coming from a 4th year history major), however, it was an incredible course. He makes you learn and the material is so valuable and interesting. I've never worked so hard but it made me a way better student.

No laptops allowed, no lecture slides besides pictures and graphs (which if its your first history class be ready to be lost), overall he just talks a lot and very fast. I find it very hard to take proper notes, not worth it for the hum credit.

While this may appear to be a geography class it is absolutely not, it is a history class taught with geography elements. Wouldn't have been such a problem if the prof was not so full of himself. Content was interesting, however he was poor at communicating the point he was trying to get across. Would not recommend taking any class with him.

I took this for another upper div GEOG course just to get a credit and boy do I regret it. In my fourth year this was in the top 3 most hated courses, as the prof acts like Geog studies are below him and honestly feels like he is looking to fail people. I have never written one of these, but I had to make sure people avoid this class at all costs.

There were quizzes every class (INCLUDING THE FIRST CLASS). lectures are boring as he just talks with NO words on the slides at all, just pics!! Took this for my Hum credits, and wouldn't recommend with this specific prof. had to print 50 pages of readings each week for the daily quizzes and exams. made me want to kms every morning before class

Lectures are not only super important but interesting, very lecture heavy however you won't want to miss a class. Taylor may seem intimidating at first however he is very helpful with readings and with improving your writing. Exams were fair and as long as you do the readings and attend class you'll do well in the class.

Joseph is a great story teller. You can learn a lot by how he teaches. His lectures have slides but you can't rely on them (there's basically no text). Definitely come to lecture and take good notes. There are a lot of readings but they'll help for the midterm and finals. Mostly essay questions. I enjoyed his class and would take another with him.
The instructor talks and talks, but is not helpful if you have a particular question on problem. He just gives his canned answers and stories. He barely discusses readings. Very frustrating.

This "environmental" history is all about what people think. Prof loves to figure out why people think what they do, even though it is of no real significance. Deadly dull and vague - pointless! If you like scientific geography, avoid this like the plague.

knows the information extremely well, but conveys it in such a monotone voice it makes it so difficult not to sleep. spent too much time on pre 1900 and dont do it if you like battles of ww1/2 cause its not in here. if you're a hist mjr and considering this class i would tell you to look elsewhere

Professor Taylor is excellent! He is very helpful and approachable too. In tutorial, he will hear you out if your opinion is different than his. I throughly enjoyed the books he assigned (some of the journals were a little dry)One of my favourite classes!
Good prof. Will be missed.

Environmental History had way more to do with history that geography, so it was tough for geography students.  His lectures were good, but his marking, i thought, was a little harsh.  Readings were sometimes confusing and sometimes heavy.  But the course was interesting.

Considering he got sacked with this survey course last minute and only 10 weeks of lectures due to Mon classes, he did an incredible job. Not only does Taylor know US history inside-out, but he's a cool guy to boot (Likes hard rock and Ducks football). Marking was fair, though the TA could've been better.

Professor Taylor III takes a personal approach to geographical history and I thoroughly enjoyed his autobiography. His stories may at first seem trivial but in fact he has a good thesis and you'll see that Taylor Saves the best for last!

Be aware of Taylor if you are Geography student he purposely gives an obvious disadvantage to Geography students in his class.  If you are a Geograpgy student I would not take his class.  His class is very fulfilling and enriching but will KILL your GPA.  PS. Be aware!contrary to popular belief, Geog 377 is not a Geography class!

It's a scary class at first..but after a while everything starts coming together and he gets nicer.  The only thing I hated was the number of readings and YES you must read all the text books (they're on the final).  Expects upper level writing. Good class, but one class is good enough with him.
Prof. was biased in his marking and in his views towards students. No need to speak your mind in his class!
Ridiculously long lectures. As he tends to use very academic language, it is too easy to zone out. Watch out though...because he doesn't post power point slides.
Extremely rigid and unhelpful. Avoid at all costs!
Great course, highly recommeded. Guy clearly loves what he teaches.
weird marking scheme
I took environmental history with Joseph. He may rub you at first as a tight ass but he's a sweety. I didn't want that class to end, it was fantastic.

SFU is extremely fortunate to have landed an environmental historian of Taylor's calibre.  He is brilliant, accessible, encouraging, and entertaining.  HIST 432 is a must-take for any student even tangentially concerned with the human-nature dialectic.

Great prof great class! Probably the best (interesting) class I've taken at SFU. You must be prepared to think and participate. The topics are interesting & informative. Changes the way you see the world, very enlightening. Tough marker. Gives breaks every hour, nice for a 4 hour seminar class.
Great proff, very down to earth, and willing to help out students. Very analytical, makes you work for your mark, very overall a very fair marker. Would recommend any class with T-diggity dog
Take home exam 17 pages (3 essays) given one week. Expects upper level writing as assumed.  It is a history course not a geography course.  If you don't like history don't take this course.
